DataElement.preferredName: Known Complete Blood Count Laboratory Test Result Performed Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A description of the complete blood count laboratory tests with known results.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Known Complete Blood Count Laboratory Test Result Performed
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Recognized, familiar, or within the scope of knowledge._A test to check the number of red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets in a sample of blood._The outcome of a laboratory test._Executed and carried through to completion.

ObjectClass.preferredName: Known Blood Cell Count Laboratory Test Result
ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Recognized, familiar, or within the scope of knowledge.:A test to check the number of red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets in a sample of blood.:The outcome of a laboratory test.

Concepts.definition: Recognized, familiar, or within the scope of knowledge.
The determination of the number of red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets in a biospecimen.
The outcome of a laboratory test.
Executed and carried through to completion.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The outcome of a laboratory test._Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A tetrameric complex of 2 molecules of hemoglobin subunit alpha (encoded by either the HBA1 or HBA2 gene) and 2 molecules of hemoglobin subunit gamma (encoded by either the HBG1 or HBG2 gene).

Concepts.definition: A tetrameric complex of 2 molecules of hemoglobin subunit alpha (encoded by either the HBA1 or HBA2 gene) and 2 molecules of hemoglobin subunit gamma (encoded by either the HBG1 or HBG2 gene).

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The number of reticulocytes present in a cubic millimeter of blood, expressed as the product of the reticulocyte percentage and the red blood cell count.

Concepts.definition: The number of reticulocytes present in a cubic millimeter of blood, expressed as the product of the reticulocyte percentage and the red blood cell count.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: platelet. An irregularly shaped disklike cytoplasmic fragment of a megakaryocyte that is shed in the marrow sinus and subsequently found in the peripheral blood where it functions in clotting. A platelet contains granules in the central part (granulomere) and, peripherally, clear protoplasm (hyalomere), but no definite nucleus; is about one-third to one-half the size of an erythrocyte; and contains no hemoglobin. (STED98)

Concepts.definition: An irregular, disc-shaped element in the blood that assists in blood clotting. Platelets are not blood cells, they are fragments of large bone marrow cells called megakaryocytes.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 9/20/22 Changed PV in Biomarker Name VD to Platelet (was previously Platelet Count, which is C51951). Then made a new Platelet Count PV for Biomarker Name VD. mr;

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The real number of white blood cells (WBC) that are neutrophils. It is derived by multiplying the WBC count by the percent of neutrophils in the differential WBC count. The normal range for ANC is 1.5 to 8.0 (1,500 to 8,000/mm3).

Concepts.definition: The real number of white blood cells (WBC) that are neutrophils. It is derived by multiplying the WBC count by the percent of neutrophils in the differential WBC count. The normal range for ANC is 1.5 to 8.0 (1,500 to 8,000/mm3).

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Blood cells that are devoid of hemoglobin, capable of ameboid motion and phagocytosis, and act as the principal components of the immune system.

Concepts.definition: Blood cells that are devoid of hemoglobin, capable of ameboid motion and phagocytosis, and act as the principal components of the immune system.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The red respiratory protein of erythrocytes, consisting of approximately 3.8% heme and 96.2% globin (64.5 KD), which as oxyhemoglobin (HbO2) transports oxygen from the lungs to the tissues where the oxygen is readily released and HbO2 becomes Hb.

Concepts.definition: The red respiratory protein of erythrocytes, consisting of approximately 3.8% heme and 96.2% globin (64.5 KD), which as oxyhemoglobin (HbO2) transports oxygen from the lungs to the tissues where the oxygen is readily released and HbO2 becomes Hb.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Granular leukocytes having a nucleus with three to five lobes connected by slender threads of chromatin, and cytoplasm containing fine inconspicuous granules and stainable by neutral dyes.

Concepts.definition: Granular leukocytes having a nucleus with three to five lobes connected by slender threads of chromatin, and cytoplasm containing fine inconspicuous granules and stainable by neutral dyes.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An immunoassay that is used to determine the amount of soluble interleukin-2 receptor subunit alpha in a patient serum sample. High levels of the soluble form of the receptor can be indicative of hematological malignancies and other neoplastic disorders.

Concepts.longName: Serum Interleukin-2 Receptor Subunit Alpha Measurement
Concepts.definition: An immunoassay that is used to determine the amount of soluble interleukin-2 receptor subunit alpha in a patient serum sample. High levels of the soluble form of the receptor can be indicative of hematological malignancies and other neoplastic disorders.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Fibrinogen; a fibrillar protein present in blood plasma; it converts to fibrin when blood clots.

Concepts.definition: A fibrillar protein present in blood plasma; it converts to fibrin during the process of blood clot formation.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: No person or thing, nobody, not any.: No person or thing, nobody, not any.

Concepts.definition: No person or thing, nobody, not any.
No person or thing, nobody, not any.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Fats composed of three fatty acid chains linked to a glycerol molecule.

Concepts.definition: Fats composed of three fatty acid chains linked to a glycerol molecule.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An iron protein complex, containing up to 23% iron, formed by the union of ferric iron with apoferritin; it is found in the intestinal mucosa, spleen, bone marrow, reticulocytes, and liver, and regulates iron storage and transport from the intestinal lumen to plasma.

Concepts.definition: An iron protein complex, containing up to 23% iron, formed by the union of ferric iron with apoferritin; it is found in the intestinal mucosa, spleen, bone marrow, reticulocytes, and liver, and regulates iron storage and transport from the intestinal lumen to plasma.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Interleukin-6 (IL-6), a glycoprotein produced by activated T-cells and a variety of other cells, induces the production of IgM by B-cells and can be used to replace feeder cells for the growth and maintenance of B-cell hybridomas in vitro.

Concepts.definition: Interleukin-6 (212 aa, ~24 kDa) is encoded by the human IL6 gene. This protein is involved in signaling affecting a wide variety of cell types including monocytes, lymphocytes, hepatocytes and nerve cells.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: C-reactive protein [precursor] (224 aa, ~25 kDa) is encoded by the CRP gene. This protein is cleaved during biological activation and is associated with host defense mechanisms and inflammatory responses.

Concepts.definition: C-reactive protein (224 aa, ~25 kDa) is encoded by the human CRP gene. This protein is cleaved during biological activation and is associated with host defense mechanisms and inflammatory responses.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The determination of the number of lymphocytes in a blood sample.

Concepts.definition: The determination of the number of lymphocytes in a blood sample.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A measure of the volume of red blood cells expressed as a percentage of the total blood volume. Normal in males is 43-49%, in females 37-43%.

Concepts.definition: A measure of the volume of red blood cells expressed as a percentage of the total blood volume. Normal in males is 43-49%, in females 37-43%.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A measurement of the total protein in a biological specimen.

Concepts.definition: A quantitative measurement of the amount of total protein present in a sample.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The initial pressure of cerebrospinal fluid when sampled via lumbar puncture. It is a surrogate measurement of intracranial pressure.

Concepts.definition: The initial pressure of cerebrospinal fluid when sampled via lumbar puncture. It is a surrogate measurement of intracranial pressure.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A family of pyridoxal phosphate-dependent enzymes involved in amino acid metabolism and in the urea and tricarboxylic acid cycles. Aspartate aminotransferase specifically and reversibly catalyzes the transfer of an amino group from L-aspartate to alpha-ketoglutarate forming oxaloacetate and L-glutamate.

Concepts.definition: A family of pyridoxal phosphate-dependent enzymes involved in amino acid metabolism and in the urea and tricarboxylic acid cycles. Aspartate aminotransferase specifically and reversibly catalyzes the transfer of an amino group from L-aspartate to alpha-ketoglutarate forming oxaloacetate and L-glutamate.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A family of pyridoxal phosphate-dependent enzymes involved in cellular nitrogen metabolism, amino acid metabolism, and liver gluconeogenesis. Alanine aminotransferase specifically and reversibly catalyzes the transfer of an amino group from L-alanine to alpha-ketoglutarate forming pyruvate and L-glutamate.

Concepts.definition: A family of pyridoxal phosphate-dependent enzymes involved in cellular nitrogen metabolism, amino acid metabolism, and liver gluconeogenesis. Alanine aminotransferase specifically and reversibly catalyzes the transfer of an amino group from L-alanine to alpha-ketoglutarate forming pyruvate and L-glutamate.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The clear portion of the blood that remains after the removal of the blood cells and the clotting proteins._A dark orange, yellow pigment that is the product of the breakdown of iron in the blood; it is conjugated in the liver and excreted in the bile.

Concepts.definition: The clear portion of the blood that remains after the removal of the blood cells and the clotting proteins.
A dark orange, yellow pigment that is the product of the breakdown of iron in the blood; it is conjugated in the liver and excreted in the bile.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The main protein in blood plasma. Low levels of serum albumin occur in people with malnutrition, inflammation, and serious liver and kidney disease.

Concepts.definition: The main protein in blood plasma. Low levels of serum albumin occur in people with malnutrition, inflammation, and serious liver and kidney disease.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The clear liquid part of the blood that remains after blood cells and clotting proteins have been removed.: The breakdown product of creatine, a constituent of muscle tissue, that is excreted by the kidney and whose serum level is used to evaluate kidney function.

Concepts.definition: The clear portion of the blood that remains after the removal of the blood cells and the clotting proteins.
The breakdown product of creatine, a constituent of muscle tissue, that is excreted by the kidney and whose serum level is used to evaluate kidney function.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A laboratory test that estimates kidney function. It is calculated using an individual's serum creatinine measurement, age, gender, and race. Actual results are reported when the estimated glomerular filtration rate is less than 60 ml/min.

Concepts.definition: A laboratory test that estimates kidney function. It is calculated using an individual's serum creatinine measurement, age, gender, and race. Actual results are reported when the estimated glomerular filtration rate is less than 60 ml/min.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A family of homotetrameric cytoplasmic enzymes involved in the conversion of L-lactate and NAD to pyruvate and NADH in the final step of anaerobic glycolysis. In vertebrates, genes for three different subunits (LDH-A, LDH-B and LDH-C) exist.

Concepts.definition: A family of homotetrameric cytoplasmic enzymes involved in the conversion of L-lactate and NAD to pyruvate and NADH in the final step of anaerobic glycolysis. In vertebrates, genes for three different subunits (LDH-A, LDH-B and LDH-C) exist.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Albumin protein in urine samples, which is a marker for kidney dysfunction. Persistently elevated concentrations of albumin in the urine can be diagnostic for kidney damage caused by diabetes, high blood pressure, heart failure, cirrhosis, or lupus.

Concepts.definition: Albumin protein in urine samples, which is a marker for kidney dysfunction. Persistently elevated concentrations of albumin in the urine can be diagnostic for kidney damage caused by diabetes, high blood pressure, heart failure, cirrhosis, or lupus.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The clear portion of the blood that remains after the removal of the blood cells and the clotting proteins._An element with atomic symbol Fe, atomic number 26, and atomic weight 55.85.

Concepts.definition: The clear portion of the blood that remains after the removal of the blood cells and the clotting proteins.
An element with atomic symbol Fe, atomic number 26, and atomic weight 55.85.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The determination of the saturation of iron binding sites on serum transferrin proteins.

Concepts.definition: The determination of the saturation of iron binding sites on serum transferrin proteins.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The clear portion of the blood that remains after the removal of the blood cells and the clotting proteins._An iron protein complex, containing up to 23% iron, formed by the union of ferric iron with apoferritin; it is found in the intestinal mucosa, spleen, bone marrow, reticulocytes, and liver, and regulates iron storage and transport from the intestinal lumen to plasma.

Concepts.definition: The clear portion of the blood that remains after the removal of the blood cells and the clotting proteins.

An iron protein complex, containing up to 23% iron, formed by the union of ferric iron with apoferritin; it is found in the intestinal mucosa, spleen, bone marrow, reticulocytes, and liver, and regulates iron storage and transport from the intestinal lumen to plasma.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: The outcome of a laboratory test.:Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

Concepts.definition: The outcome of a laboratory test.
Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.
